subtypeQuestions.text: While I care about my relationships and social standing, improving my financial situation and personal abilities is a higher priority for me.
I care about my social responsibilities and make the effort to fulfill them. I also expect everyone to do their part.
Even in my close relationships, I focus more on maintaining my boundaries and being self-sufficient than fully sharing my inner world.
I prioritize emotionally fulfilling relationships where I feel special, even if it means sacrificing my comfort or preferences.
When I enter a social environment, I prefer to interact with as many people as possible, rather than just a few one-on-one.
When I’m with someone in a social setting and they show care or attention to others, I feel overlooked or neglected.
Because I value being a functional and respected member of my group, I fulfill my responsibilities diligently and with care.
When an issue arises in a relationship, I tend to express my feelings quickly and confront the situation rather than overthinking how to say it.
When I have conflict with someone, even if it may hurt or be hurtful, I want to express all of my feelings and expect the other person to do the same.
Being useful and making self-sacrificing efforts within a group that shares my ideals is more meaningful and satisfying to me than close one-on-one relationships.
Even though being alone may protect me from relationship struggles, I still long for a passionate relationship—even if it’s difficult.
In order to protect my peace of mind and self-sufficiency, I feel the need to limit close and social relationships, which can be perceived as selfish.
I care about the work and interests of those close to me, but I always expect them to spend special time with me and show affection.
I believe that the primary goal of human relationships should be to build an ideal society rather than to meet individual needs.
In my work, social, and daily life, who I do things with matters more to me than what I’m doing.
Even in close relationships, what bothers me most is when people pry into my inner world, expect deep emotional closeness, or pressure me to join social activities.
I want to be fully understood by sharing my inner world completely, so I seek relationships where I can express my emotions openly and without limits.
I prefer spending time alone to participating in social or romantic activities.
I generally avoid people who are highly social or expect a lot of emotional intimacy.
When I learn something new or gain a skill, my first thought is how I can make it beneficial for as many people as possible.
While social status is somewhat important to me, my main priority is having a relationship where I can deeply share my inner world.
When I enter a room, I first focus on the physical conditions and where I’ll feel comfortable before noticing the people.
In close relationships, I don’t want any distance or boundaries—I seek deep, mutual engagement and passionate connection.
For the sake of a group or community ideal, I tend to easily set aside my own personal expectations.
While intense relationships can seem appealing, the energy and effort required to maintain them feels exhausting in the long run.
I’m very drawn to the life stories of people who’ve dedicated themselves to society and created social change—I see myself in them and take inspiration from their example.
Although I somewhat enjoy socializing and forming close friendships, I often find myself spending most of my time alone.
In my relationships, I focus intensely on my partner’s words and actions, and I express my emotions clearly as a result.
While I want fulfilling personal and social relationships, my main priority is to create a self-sufficient, secure, and comfortable space within my own boundaries.
I care deeply about taking active steps toward my social ideals and responsibilities, even if it means sacrificing personal comfort.
